body: If you have no further comments, I will close this PR after a couple of days.

This change looks good to me. There is a weird add in the docs about Microsoft Azure which needs to be removed.

Can you check that this change still works if someone messes up with trailing/slashes? If so I would recommend using `posixpath.join` rather than string concatenation.

Once those two issues are addressed, I am +1 on this.

Thank you @bolkedebruin :D. I've started setting up a blog post to write up over the weekend, and am doing a refactor of the main PR based on these changes. When the blog post is written, is there any publication that is usually used for this stuff? Or should I publish it separately and post to the user group?
Fixed my single documentation line that was over 90 characters. Redestroyed history.

@bolkedebruin the `timestamp` column is calling the utcnow() in the XCom class attributes, only once, resulting in all xcoms having the exact same timestamp.

Use something like this
```python
    timestamp = Column(
        DateTime(timezone=True), default=timezone.utcnow, nullable=False)
```

As with the other PR:

Why is `app.config['APPLICATION_ROOT'] = "/abc/def"` not used? This removed the need for all reconfig of base urls.

Secondly, I am not a fan of adding another config option for this, as I don't think it is required.  Why not use the base_url and use a split?

Furthermore please add some tests that cover this.
I think there are 3 PRs that somewhat address the same issues. I would like to see convergence before merging any of them

Ah, that makes sense. Just looked through the documentation again, here does mention setting connections referenced in the DAG. http://airflow.readthedocs.io/en/latest/concepts.html?highlight=environment%20variable#connections, so we're good. Feel free to close this PR. Thank you!
To be clear, we should pass a callable, rather than a datetime, as the default column value
Rebased
@criccomini PTAL, thank you.

Hi @andyxhadji, My PR is more or less done: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2875 Please take a look if you agree with the changes.

The deprecated import structure needs to stay until Airflow 2.0, I don't like it either, but we have to keep some backward compatibility until then.

I think sensors.py should still exist, contain a deprecation warning, but still have the sensors available in that package (until 2.0), otherwise DAGs will break with no warning, and it’s easy to maintain back compat in this case
LGTM, this change will make maintenance/testing of sensors much easier. I would love for this to be merged before I hack on [AIRFLOW-2001](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2001).

This looks pretty cool. Couple of things:

* Can you fix the flake8 errors?
* I think it is highly beneficial to have a bit of documentation when you would want to use what kind of weight rule, preferably with an example
* Can you add a test that tests not happy flow? Ie. an invalid weight rule?

Looks great, awesome work! I think we should keep sensors.py for now with a deprecation warning - I can add their removal to the scope of [AIRFLOW-1922](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1922) for 2.0.

Much better, thanks
`flask_caching` is updated as early as December 2017, so that's much better :)

I think the `default` value should be a callable, not a datetime.

If you pass a datetime, every record gets the exact same timestamp.

Affects my PR [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2902).

Good point. I’ll have a look

Small nit, overall LGTM.

Of course you send it over. It you want to make it very fancy you could add it to the tutorial or separate in the documentation as well.
@Fokko can you review this?
@andrewmchen could you review please?
Edited the files as per the suggestions. @jgao54

This PR removed two quiet important things:
- support for default boto credential handling https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/eb2f589099b87743482c2eb16261b49e284dcd96/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L166
- support for sts/assume role https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/eb2f589099b87743482c2eb16261b49e284dcd96/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L185

Are there any plans/issues to address/reintroduce this?

@simonvanderveldt have you tested that it doesn't? My understanding is that the upgrade from boto to boto3 library means it falls back to assume the environment variables and failing that the host IAM role implicitly. I will double check that when I am at a computer.

> @simonvanderveldt have you tested that it doesn't? My understanding is that the upgrade from boto to boto3 library means it falls back to assume the environment variables and failing that the host IAM role implicitly. I will double check that when I am at a computer.

@davoscollective Thanks for the quick response. And yeah, I have tested it and assumerole based credentials don't work, that's why I started looking into the code.
That one is definitely not working because it has been removed in its entirety :)

What might be the case regarding the fallback to boto3 credential handling is that it does actually work but since it doesn't do any assume role call I have to assumerole myself and set the credentials that that call returns. I'll give that a try and report back.
Waiting on #2949

Are you running on an EC2 with an IAM role attached that has a policy that allows writing to the S3 bucket? 
http://boto3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/configuration.html
In the docs there's a list of 8 places boto3 looks for credentials. #6 is an explicit assume role provider, number 8 is EC2 instance IAM metadata.
I wonder if you don't have some other thing preventing S3 access. Do you see any specific errors?

I reread those docs about boto3 credentials and I think the only valid use case for assume role or temporary sessions is where you need airflow to access a different AWS account from where it is hosted, perhaps an account belonging to another organization or division within the same organization. If that's not the case IAM roles are the recommended best practice, and a lot simpler to manage. That being said there will be some that have that use case so removing this ability is not ideal.

> Are you running on an EC2 with an IAM role attached that has a policy that allows writing to the S3 bucket?
> http://boto3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/configuration.html
> In the docs there's a list of 8 places boto3 looks for credentials. #6 is an explicit assume role provider, number 8 is EC2 instance IAM metadata.

No, I'm running Airflow locally in a docker container and use assumerole to access resources within an AWS account. I'll provide some context, sorry for the wall of text.

The fact that I'm running Airflow in a container makes the regular way of using assumerole (adding a profile to `~/.aws/config` and passing that profile's name to `boto3.client()` or setting the `AWS_PROFILE` env var) pretty impractical/impossible because I can't properly volume mount my `~/.aws/config`. So Airflow's option to use assumerole by setting the role-arn was very welcome.
For people who want to use assumerole when running Airflow locally it would be enough for them to set `AWS_PROFILE` (or the option to set the profile name in the extra config should be added again and Airflow does the assumerole call).

Anyway, the fallback to boto3 credentials is working, I did the assumerole call myself using AWS cli and set the `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID`, `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY` and `AWS_SESSION_TOKEN` env vars based on that. After that logging to S3 worked using these credentials.
Doing this is not ideal because I have to do the assumerole call myself and then convert the response from AWS to env vars and the credentials time out whereas if you leave the assumerole action to boto3 it gets renewed automatically.

> I wonder if you don't have some other thing preventing S3 access. Do you see any specific errors?

No, there are no details for the errors, mainly because of this nice line :x
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/4ce4faaeae7a76d97defcf9a9d3304ac9d78b9bd/airflow/utils/log/s3_task_handler.py#L166

@CannibalVox Can you rebase?

@bolkedebruin I'm currently working on the Google Cloud, perhaps @NielsZeilemaker can take a look at it :)

@jgao54  Regarding the difference between `self.service.tables().insert` and `self.service.jobs().insert`:

I couldn't create an external table with `self.service.jobs().insert`. It can be done by using `configuration.query.tableDefinitions` but in that you need to specify the query as well in the query parameter.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8811558/35019763-8646b1cc-fb20-11e7-99b7-349968c7eb08.png)

So in that case, I will be able to create an external table only if I want to query it immediately.

While the `self.service.tables().insert` create an external table that points to a specific file(s) in Cloud Storage. So, the table is not empty. It is similar to an external table in Hive. Although you can just create a materialised empty BigQuery table using `self.service.tables().insert` by not passing `externalDataConfiguration`.

I am also planning to create a different operator called `BigQueryCreateTable` operator that would create an Empty BQ table or an external table that points to data files in GCS. But would do that in a new PR possibly next week.

After some investigation, I think I understand where the problem is coming from.

In the current setup of operators, it is not possible to save a state inside of the operators such as pid or in our case, the id of a spark job.
The reason is that there is a crucial difference between the saved task (the operator) and a job (a TaskInstance).

When you clear a job, it will clear the TaskInstances and not the tasks (and therefore has no previous state which you saved in the operator.

How I see a possible solution is a mechanism which you can use inside of an operator to specify what kind of information you want to save. And this state can be accessed from a TaskInstance.

@bolkedebruin Yes, it's been fairly hard to get this simple PR through to be honest. This has however been in production (definitely not using application-level Kerberos however) with us for quite some time now at the very least. I would very much love getting it merged so I can stop using a fork :)

Side note: would you be interested in a helm chart for k8s? I can contribute what I came up with here in a separate PR if interested. It's fully generic at this point, as well as allows everything to be overridden easily. Up to you.

This entire diff is an unfortunate necessity due to worker logs being accessed via an API, requiring name-based access from web to the workers. The real fix IMO is to avoid this altogether, but that is a task for another day, for me, at the very least. :)

Thanks for the comments, I also reverted `airflow/security/kerberos.py`, please let me know if that is alright by you. For consistency's sake, I do feel that a hostname override should always apply, but in the end, it is fully up to you and either way does not affect our configuration, so I'm happy with either.
@saguziel please have a look. Thanks!

I think the proper fix is to install a signal handler inside the right process, and then have the listener process (this is the LocalExecutor I think, the `airflow run --local` process) send a sigint to the "operator" process (this is the one with `airflow run --raw` in the args). That way we don't have to worry about what is or isn't pickleable, or even about persisting extra things to the DB.
tests please.

Thanks for working on this @milanvdm.

@ashb 
Your approach makes sense. Looks like the signal handler is already installed  in the "operator" process (`airflow run --raw`) [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1476-L1481), but this process never received any SIGTERM signal from the "listener" (`airflow run --local`). 

I *think* you may be referring to the LocalTaskJob not the LocalExecutor, which is what `airflow run --local` instantiates, and it starts/terminates the "operator" process (via the task runner).  So imho the task_runner.terminate() should be responsible for sending the signal to the "operator" process. Right now it only sends the signal to the _children_ of the "operator" process via [`kill_process_tree`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/task/task_runner/bash_task_runner.py#L36), but not itself. 

One way to fix the issue is to modify the terminate method to something roughly like the following:
```
    def terminate(self):
        if self.process and psutil.pid_exists(self.process.pid):
            kill_process_tree(self.log, self.process.pid)
        root_process = psutil.Process(self.process.pid)
        root_process.terminate()
```
I'm not sure why the root process is not signaled in the first place, so perhaps there's some other implications I'm overlooking.

That said, I don't have any experience running Airflow with Celery (we run LocalExecutor), but I am also curious about the question on handling state in distributed context.

What I meant was: please add an unit test for your function and an integration test that check whether it works as expected.

And yes you are supposed to fix flake8 errors although they might be slightly outside of the scope of your PR, this increases the the quality of the whole code base and we had to start somewhere. Thus yes the flake8 build needs to succeed.

Normally tests will catch any errors in imports. If it really becomes an issue (the tests will fail either way) sometimes a no-qa for flake8 will be acceptable. However, not by default.

Looks like the three tests that are failing in all builds are because of a change in SQLAlchemy 1.2 that broke flask-admin: https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/issues/1583

Consequently, this will have to wait until flask-admin has a fix out --  likely when https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/pull/1586 gets into a release.
What exactly do you propose that I test for with this simple function?
And isn't that enforced crowdsourced cleanup?
If you're going to do such things, you should look at at least running yapf or autopep8 across this codebase first, don't you think?

Ok this is ready to merge now, thanks to @bolkedebruin's change in #2949, we're now consistently pulling the most recent xcom value. The test has been updated to assert that.

It is crowd sourced indeed. This was deemed the proper way by the community, as an autopep would impact the whole code base immediately and would invalidate all outstanding PRs.
